title: 108_s1392
content: Nutritional improvement for children in child nutrition programs. The Secretary will establish a program to provide grants to elementary and secondary schools to promote healthy school nutrition environments and assess their impact on children's health. At least 75 percent of selected schools must participate in the program. The program will provide grants to schools where at least 50% of students are eligible for free or reduced-price meals. Schools selected must represent rural, urban, and suburban areas, as well as elementary, middle, and secondary schools. Selected schools must meet specific requirements to receive a grant. The program will provide grants to schools with a high percentage of students eligible for free or reduced-price meals. Schools must have comprehensive plans involving community stakeholders and a strategy for maintaining healthy nutrition environments. Schools must submit grant applications by May 1, 2004, and grant awards will be effective by July 15, 2004. The Secretary will seek input from nutrition, health, and education organizations to establish criteria for a healthy school environment, including providing meals that meet nutritional standards. The Secretary will establish nutritional standards for school meals, promote fruit and vegetable consumption, provide nutrition education, and set other criteria for a healthy school environment. To be eligible for a grant under this subsection, a school must submit a healthy school nutrition environment plan to the Secretary. Grants will be provided to selected schools for fiscal years 2005 through 2008, and evaluations will be conducted on a sample of grant-receiving schools by the Secretary. The evaluation of schools receiving grants will measure the effects of a healthy school nutrition environment on overweight children, dietary intake, nutrition education, time to eat, physical activities, parental and student attitudes, and funding issues. The Secretary will submit reports to the Committee on Education and the Workforce of the House. The Secretary will submit reports to the Committee on Education and the Workforce of the House and the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate by December 31, 2005, and December 31, 2007, respectively. $10,000,000 will be transferred from the Treasury to the Secretary of Agriculture on October 1, 2003, to carry out the evaluation of schools receiving grants. On October 1, 2003, $10,000,000 will be transferred to the Secretary of Agriculture for school evaluations. From October 1, 2004, to October 1, 2006, $35,000,000 will be transferred annually. The Secretary can use the funds without further appropriation and they will remain available until expended. Up to $5,000,000 will be used for evaluations. The regulations under the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 may include provisions that regulate the service of competitive foods in schools in competition with authorized programs. The regulations under the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 govern the service of competitive foods in schools during the school day. These regulations do not override state and local rules on competitive foods that align with nutritional goals. Proceeds from competitive food sales must benefit the schools or approved student organizations. Different needs of elementary schools are considered in these regulations. The Secretary of Agriculture shall implement recommendations from the Institute of Medicine regarding the regulation of competitive foods in schools. The Secretary of Agriculture will promulgate regulations based on recommendations from the Institute of Medicine regarding the Child Nutrition Act of 1966. A report will be submitted to relevant committees in Congress within a year of receiving the final recommendations. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit a report to Congress describing actions taken under the Child Nutrition Act of 1966.
